qas.question: What happens first if a Directive's deadline for implementation is not met?

answers.text: the member state cannot enforce conflicting laws, and a citizen may rely on the Directive in such an action
the member state cannot enforce conflicting laws
the member state cannot enforce conflicting laws

qas.question: What happens secondly if a Directive's deadline is not met?

answers.text: a citizen or company can invoke a Directive, not just in a dispute with a public authority, but in a dispute with another citizen or company
a citizen may rely on the Directive in such an action (so called "vertical" direct effect)
a citizen may rely on the Directive in such an action

qas.question: How long did Ms Kucukdeveci work for Swedex Gmbh & Co KG before she was dismissed?
Which company did Mrs Foster work for?
At what age did British Gas plc force their workers to retire?

answers.text: women retire at age 60 and men at 65
women retire at age 60 and men at 65
women retire at age 60 and men at 65

plausible_answers.text: the member state cannot enforce conflicting laws, and a citizen may rely on the Directive in such an action

qas.question: What happens if the Directive's deadline is met?

plausible_answers.text: a Directive 73/173/EEC on packaging and labelling solvents by the deadline

qas.question: What did the Italian government not fail to implement?
What a a citizen or company not invoke?

plausible_answers.text: it can be invoked between private non-state parties before its deadline for implementation

qas.question: What happens if a Directive doe snot give expression to a "general principle"of EU law?
Who did Ms Kucukdeveci not work for?

context: First, if a Directive's deadline for implementation is not met, <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><b5_0>the member state cannot enforce conflicting laws<a0_2/><a0_1/>, and <a1_1><a1_2>a citizen may rely on the Directive in such an action<b5_0/><a1_2/><a0_0/> (so called "vertical" direct effect)<a1_1/>. So, in Pubblico Ministero v Ratti because the Italian government had failed to implement <b6_0>a Directive 73/173/EEC on packaging and labelling solvents by the deadline<b6_0/>, it was estopped from enforcing a conflicting national law from 1963 against Mr Ratti's solvent and varnish business. A member state could "not rely, as against individuals, on its own failure to perform the obligations which the Directive entails." Second, <a1_0>a citizen or company can invoke a <b7_0>Directive<b7_0/>, not just in a dispute with a public authority, but in a dispute with another citizen or company<a1_0/>. So, in CIA Security v Signalson and Securitel the Court of Justice held that a business called CIA Security could defend itself from allegations by competitors that it had not complied with a Belgian decree from 1991 about alarm systems, on the basis that it had not been notified to the Commission as a Directive required. Third, if a Directive gives expression to a "general principle" of EU law, <b8_0>it can be invoked between private non-state parties before its deadline for implementation<b8_0/>. This follows from Kücükdeveci v Swedex GmbH & Co KG where the German Civil Code §622 stated that the years people worked under the age of 25 would not count towards the increasing statutory notice before dismissal. Ms Kücükdeveci worked for <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2>10 years<a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/>, from age 18 to 28, for Swedex <b9_0>GmbH & Co KG<b9_0/> before her dismissal. She claimed that the law not counting her years under age 25 was unlawful age discrimination under the Employment Equality Framework Directive. The Court of Justice held that the Directive could be relied on by her because equality was also a general principle of EU law. Third, if the defendant is an emanation of the state, even if not central government, it can still be bound by Directives. In Foster v British Gas plc the Court of Justice held that Mrs Foster was entitled to bring a sex discrimination claim against her employer, <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2>British Gas plc<a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/>, which made <a4_0><a4_1><a4_2>women retire at age 60 and men at 65<a4_2/><a4_1/><a4_0/>, if (1) pursuant to a state measure, (2) it provided a public service, and (3) had special powers. This could also be true if the enterprise is privatised, as it was held with a water company that was responsible for basic water provision.
